info.title: Hello! My name is Farid
info.subhead: I'm a web developer, musician, and electrical engineer. I do stuff on computers, and sometimes in meatspace.
info.text:
I have a strong belief that technology can have a positive impact on society, and I am particularly concerned with using technology in a socially just, civic manner.

I currently spend my days as senior developer at Dimagi, where we are building an open-source mobile platform for frontline health workers in low-resource settings, that allows anyone to build mobile applications to use for data collection.

Sometimes, I blog here.

info.title: Dimagi (2015–Present)
info.subhead:
Dimagi builds CommCare, an open-source mobile platform for frontline health workers in low-resource settings, that allows anyone to build mobile applications to use for data collection.

I worked on all levels of the core product, while playing a major role in Dimagi’s biggest project: eNikshay. All of the code I’ve written while at Dimagi is on Github.
info.text:
eNikshay Project

National-scale project funded by the Gates Foundation to digitize all tuberculosis workflows across India. Winner of the 2018 Elastic cause award. I lead the systems integration team, acted as tech-team liaison and built a major portion of the applications to track all TB patients in India.

  • Designed, specced, and built system integrations to connect CommCare with multiple external systems, including (undocumented) government databases. I lead a team of four people at Dimagi to build and support our side;
  • Built mobile and web applications that manage treatment protocols, drug adherence, contact tracing, and drug and test vouchers across India’s public and private healthcare sectors for TB patients;
  • Oversaw the design and implementation of reports in use by government employees at all levels of the Indian government;
  • Acted as team liaison between the technical and non-technical teams. Translated non-technical requirements into technical specifications. Attended meetings with the Gates Foundation and government ministers;
  • Worked on multiple performance improvements to Dimagi’s core platform;

Product Ownership Areas

  • Core member, Solutions Team: I am responsible for designing and building tools for our advanced application builders and data users across the globe. Past projects include building reports that users can use to arbitrarily query their own data based on an internal DSL, and a revamp of the tools we provide to users to test and QA applications built in CommCare.
  • Case Search: Designed and built a system using Elasticsearch to index a user’s unstructured data, that allows users to to add arbitrary search parameters to their applications;
  • Extension case sync algorithms: Designed and implemented a new sync algorithm for phone data;
  • MOTECH data integration hub: Designed and helped create the business case around a framework that allows users to integrate CommCare with other popular mHealth applications.

info.title: Provender (2013–2015)
info.subhead: Provender leveraged advances in technology and connectivity to remake the path from farmer’s field to professional kitchen, offering new ways for farmers to access markets, reduce waste, and improve sustainability, and creating new channels for food service providers to purchase and discover fresh, local produce.
info.text:
I was a senior developer at Provender working across the stack. Over my time there I, among other things:
  • Re-designed and re-built the whole of Provender's marketplace in Backbone.js using an iterative design process that meticulously took real user experiences into account.
  • Designed and built a full-suite of farmside tools
  • Implemented complex business logic in Ruby to create two-sided personalized marketplaces for farms and restaurants which incorporated location and schedule information
  • Implemented multi-faceted product search with Elasticsearch
  • Created training materials and documentation for internal and external use
  • Responded to technical support queries from farmers and other non-technical users

Some of the technologies I used at Provender included: PostgreSQL, PostGIS, Ruby on Rails, Elasticsearch, Backbone.js, ZURB Foundation, Rspec, Mocha, Coffeescript, Ruby;

info.title: Interview with Stephen Platt
info.subhead: The author of Autumn in the Heavenly Kingdom talks cannibalism, rebellion and how little he still knows about China
info.text:
The Taiping civil war, one of the most gruesome civil wars in history, claimed the lives of 20 million people. The uprising, which Steven Platt describes in all its gory detail in Autumn in the Heavenly Kingdom (Knopf), started after Hong Xiuquan, a failed civil servant, hallucinated that he was the brother of Jesus Christ and was chosen by God to rid China of the ruling Manchu 'demons.'' In this narrative history, Platt takes us on a journey through a tumultuous China as a home-grown rebellion, built on the power of the poor and a leader who preaches Confucian-infused Protestantism, is set to drastically change the country's status quo.

When bumbling British and American troops, scared that their precious supply of tea is about to be cut off, put their weight behind the prevailing Qing dynasty, the tale becomes one of mistrust, miscommunication and misunderstanding. The moral of this story for us, says Platt, has to do with the dangers of assuming that you can understand a foreign civil war on your own terms. By the end of the tale, Hong Rengan, prime minister of the Heavenly Kingdom, has no faith left. 'I have never met a good foreigner,' he says.

Read more here.

info.title: Facility for Architectural Research in Media and Mediation (2012)
info.subhead: Modelling the Methodologies of our Time. With Prof. Michael Jemtrud.
info.text:
This research-creation project aimed to investigate the qualities, biases, and benefits inherent in specific contemporary technological modes of creation;
  • I researched the uses of sensors in architecture and created a critical framework to unpack the nature of the effects this technology had on both the experience of architecture and the creative process;
  • To this end, created interactive simulations in Processing and the xBox Kinect in order to model the 'methodologies of our time', and provide insight into the ways new technologies are transforming the creative process.

    Technical skills:

  • In-depth knowledge of cutting-edge sensor systems and their potential uses in architecture and other creative endeavours;
  • 3-D graphics and visualization coding in Processing;
  • DSP algorithms to analyze input data from Kinect;
  • Ability to analyse the greater importance of the tools and systems used.

info.title: McGill Haptics Lab (2008)
info.subhead: An fMRI compatible finger stimulator. With Prof. Vincent Hayward.
info.text: Built an electronic device to work inside an fMRI machine (no metal or magnets) to stimulate a forefinger for an experiment to understand the functioning of the brain when a forefinger is stimulated. This required a custom-built digital-to-analogue converter with a parallel port interface that sent messages to an ultrasonic motor.

info.title: The Flat Bike Collective (2009-2012)
info.subhead: Collective Member and Volunteer Mechanic
info.text:
I was an active participant in the day-to-day running of The Flat Bike collective, one of Montreal's most used bike collectives, where people are empowered with tools and knowledge to fix their own bicycles. I gave weekly workshops on bicycle mechanics, both to volunteers and shop patrons, and volunteered as an “experienced mechanic” during shop open hours once a week.

Key projects:

  • Collaboration with the Montreal Native Friendship centre, where youth came on the weekends to learn about bicycle mechanics
  • Creation of winter riding materials, with tips and tricks of how to brave Montreal's winters on two wheels. These are now sold at Fitz & Follwell.
